content: Make an appointment with your doctor. If you feel there are some small changes that you need or want to make in your life to be healthier, it wouldn't hurt to see your doctor prior to making any changes. They can review your medical history, weight and let you know what changes might be the most beneficial to you. Set goals for yourself. Small goals are often the most appealing as they are the easiest to reach. If your goals are too high and you are unable to reach them in a timely manner, you may become discouraged. Set small goals that ultimately lead up to your larger goal. It will help provide you with the motivation to make and keep lifestyle changes. When setting your goals make sure they are realistic, timely, and specific. These qualities make goals that are easier to meet in the long-term. For example, instead of a goal of "I want to boost my endurance," make your goal "I want to be able to swim five laps in my pool without needing to stop." Also consider whether you need smaller goals to meet a larger, more long-term goal. For example, if you want to run five miles, you might make a goal to run a 5k (which is 3.1 miles) as an intermediary goal. Write down realistic lifestyle changes. Remember that too many lifestyle changes at once is a recipe for failure. It is important that you only try to implement so many changes at once. Think about what lifestyle changes you need to make in order to achieve your goals. If you don't think you'll be willing to make the lifestyle changes needed to meet your goal, revisit your goals and change them as needed. Lifestyle changes are small changes in behavior that may result in improved health or well-being. Studies show that small lifestyle changes over long periods of time are more sustainable. [2] Examples of lifestyle changes include: replacing desserts with fruit or taking the stairs instead of the elevator. The lifestyle changes you want to make may also help you make, change, or come up with additional goals. For example, you might want to eat healthier. A goal could be to eat a fruit or vegetable every day. Assign a timeline for your lifestyle changes. Even with small lifestyle changes, trying to accomplish multiple items at one time can be difficult and hard to keep up with. [3] Assigning your lifestyle changes to an ordered timeline can help you be more successful. Try to note which changes you'll make first, second, third, etc. After you've come up with your goals and the lifestyle changes to help you meet them, assign an order to your list. For example: Week 1: Give up soda; Week 2: Take the stairs instead of the elevator; Week 3: Go to bed earlier. Continuously reevaluate your progress. If you notice one lifestyle change in particular is giving you trouble, rework your timeline to account for that. Give yourself time to make these changes a habit. Again, if you try to work on multiple items at one time, you may be less successful. Find support. It is much easier to stick to a plan when others know you're doing it. Get a support system and lean on them when necessary. Telling family, friends or coworkers about your new lifestyle changes may help keep you motivated. [4] It's also helpful to surround yourself with people who are also on the same path as you making small lifestyle changes to help improve their health. You can bounce ideas off each other or work on similar goals at the same time. Drink more water. A common goal to improve your overall health is to ditch the sugary drinks and increase water intake within reason. This is a great goal as water is essential to your hydration and health. [5] Increasing water consumption is a virtually free and painless way to instantly make a positive change for yourself. Your long-term goal should be to drink about 64 oz or 2 L of clear, sugar-free fluids every day. [6] Ditch sweetened beverages. Drinking more water is great, but skipping the sweetened beverages will help reduce your overall calorie intake. [7] Start drinking more water gradually. Add in one glass or one bottle of water than usual. Or, swap out one soda or one energy drink for an equivalent amount of water. Slowly increase the amount of water you drink and decrease the number of sweetened beverages you drink. Don't drink your fruits. Drink less fruit juice and instead get nutrients from whole fruit. You'll get the added benefit of the fruit fiber in addition to missing out on the added sugar of fruit juice. Beware of water intoxication . This is caused by drinking a large amount of water in a short time. When one is suffering from water intoxication , it brings the level of sodium (salt) to a dangerously low level. Water intoxication is a rare condition. It should be taken seriously, however, as it can have fatal results. [8] Drink water before a meal. While increasing the amount of water you drink, you can also be strategic about when you drink it. Drinking a big glass of water (about eight oz) right before a meal or snack can help decrease your appetite and how many calories you consume. [9] Eat a fruit and vegetable every day. Eating enough fruits and vegetables is key for a healthy lifestyle and diet, since these foods are essential sources of vitamins, minerals and antioxidants. However, eating the recommended seven to nine servings of fruits and vegetables everyday may be daunting or difficult. [10] If you're not a big fruit or vegetable eater, make a list of your top five favorite fruits and vegetables. Start by adding in just one serving of fruit or vegetables a day. As you get comfortable with this goal, add two servings a day. If you dislike many fruits and vegetables, go to the grocery and pick out something new or unfamiliar to you. Or try an item that you haven't had in a while. Keep fresh fruit on the counter and vegetables cut, washed, and ready to eat in the fridge. The less preparation needed, the more likely you'll include them in your diet. If you enjoy a sweet after dinner, try having fruit with your dessert. Keep in mind that fruit skins have the most nutrients. Say, in an apple, keep the skin on. Don't eat pomegranate skins, even though that is where the nutrients are. Choose whole grains when you can. Whole grains are minimally processed grains that are higher in fiber, protein, and other nutrients compared to refined grains (white bread or plain pasta). [11] They may have a more nutty flavor and chewy texture, which may not be enjoyable by all people. If you typically eat refined grains, start by making about half of your grain choices whole grains. As you get more comfortable with this goal, you can work up to making more of your grain choices whole grains. Whole grain foods to try include: 100% whole wheat pasta, oatmeal, quinoa, brown rice or 100% whole wheat bread. Try a variety of whole grains and a variety of brands of whole grains. For example, try 100% whole wheat pasta. If you don't like it, try another brand of 100% whole wheat pasta as each brand has a slightly different flavor. Eat healthy snacks. Making lifestyle changes to be healthier doesn't mean you can't enjoy a snack. In fact, having a snack can help manage and control hunger and support weight loss. [12] Healthy snacks should contain some lean protein and a fruit or a vegetable. However, start slowly changing your snacks for a lasting change. For example, if you normally have a small bag of chips in the afternoon, try swapping to a small bag of whole grain chips with salsa. Pack your lunch. Studies show that packing your lunch can help cut down on your overall calorie intake (and food costs). [13] Brown-bagging your lunch will give you more control over what foods you eat and how they're prepared. If you typically eat lunch out everyday, start by packing your lunch just one to two days a week. Also pack an afternoon snack if you typically stop by the vending machine to grab an afternoon pick-me-up. Eat less high fructose corn syrup (HFCS). Fructose is a sugar that goes through your body, like the glucose sugar that your body usually uses. However, fructose has its own pathways. It can turn into glucose for your muscles and brain to use, but it tends to go straight toward making fat in your body, when there is too much sugar in your body. Fructose is found in fruits and vegetables naturally, but it is found in high concentrations artificially, as High Fructose Corn Syrup. [14] High fructose corn syrup is used as a sweetener so much that we don't realize it can be found in almost everything. It is in lots of processed foods, pastries, and beverages, so eating less of it might be a little difficult, but it's good to be aware of what you're eating. Walk more throughout the day. Finding time to exercise can be difficult, especially with busy schedules or long commutes. Start adding in physical activity by increasing how many steps or how much you walk during the day. Increasing physical activity is a great change to make to help improve your overall health. Exercise has been shown to help improve mood, increase energy, and decrease your risk of heart disease and high blood pressure. [15] Even without planned exercise each day, adding extra steps can be beneficial to your health. Try: taking the stairs instead of the elevator, parking father away, delivering messages in person instead of email at work, walking while you talk on the phone, or take a walk on your lunch break. You burn more calories walking at a faster pace than you do at a slower pace. You can also consider purchasing a pedometer to help see how many steps you take and monitor your progress of increasing your total steps. Try the "one mile rule." This means that you can walk to the store, school, work or other locations if they are less than one mile away (and it's a safe walk). Skip taking the bus or driving! Add in planned cardio. Additional exercise outside of lifestyle activity (like taking the stairs), greatly adds to the health benefits provided by exercise. Plan cardio so that you're getting targeted exercise that benefits your heart and overall health. You'll see additional improvements in weight, mood and overall health. [16] The USDA states that you should aim for 150 minutes or about 2 1/2 hours of moderate-intensity physical activity each week. [17] Moderate intensity activity is any exercise that increases your heart rate and makes you breathe harder and work up a slight sweat. If this recommendation is too much, start with half of that amount. Or break up that time in small bits. For example, a brisk 10-minute walk at breakfast, lunch and dinner five days a week meets your 150-minute goal. Also, if you cannot do moderate intensity at first, do 150 minutes of lower intensity exercises. For example, walking counts as a lower intensity exercise. Any activity is better than none. Add in some resistance training. Not all strength training exercises require you to spend time at the gym. There are plenty of easy to do exercises at home that require little to no equipment. It's recommended to include 20 minutes of strength training two days a week. Including strength training helps build lean muscle mass which can increase your metabolism and how many calories your body burns at rest. [18] Easy, no equipment required exercises include: lunges, push-ups, sit-ups, squats, or wall sits. Look for social, fun exercise opportunities. Go to the pool with your little brother, take a walk with your best friend, chase your daughter around the playground, or play backyard sports with your family. Move while you watch TV. If you aren't ready for the gym or more intense exercise, try moving while you watch your favorite TV programs. Get up during the commercial breaks and fit in a few minutes of activity. Try running or walking in place, or some strength training exercises. Since commercial breaks are about two minutes, you can burn about 270 calories during two hours of TV time. [19] Sit on an exercise ball in front of your desk or TV.

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Healthier-Without-a-Dramatic-Lifestyle-Change">How to Be Healthier Without a Dramatic Lifestyle Change</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Claudia Carberry, RD</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Planning_for_a_Healthier_Lifestyle_sub" id="">Planning for a Healthier Lifestyle</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Changing_Your_Eating_Habits_sub" id="">Changing Your Eating Habits</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Adding_in_Physical_Activity_sub" id="">Adding in Physical Activity</a>
<a class="" href="#Questions_and_Answers_sub" id="qa_toc">Ask a Question</a>
<a class="" href="#relatedwikihows" id="rwh_toc">Related Articles</a>
<a class="toc_ref" href="#references" id="">References</a>
</p>
<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=claudiacarberry%2Crd#claudiacarberry%2Crd">Claudia Carberry, RD</a>. Claudia Carberry is an Outpatient Dietitian at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences. She received her MS in Nutrition from the University of Tennessee Knoxville in 2010.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">19 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Many diet or exercise programs require major lifestyle changes, long-term commitments and or pricey products or equipment. For a lot people, these programs are not reasonable or even affordable. In addition, studies have shown that drastic or large lifestyle changes or changes that aren't realistic are not easily maintained long-term.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup> However, making smaller lifestyle changes over long periods of time may be easier, more affordable and more enjoyable for many people.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Planning_for_a_Healthier_Lifestyle_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Planning_for_a_Healthier_Lifestyle">Planning for a Healthier Lifestyle</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Choose-the-Right-Divorce-Lawyer-Step-7-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5612690" href="#/Image:Choose-the-Right-Divorce-Lawyer-Step-7-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Choose the Right Divorce Lawyer Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e9/Choose-the-Right-Divorce-Lawyer-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Choose-the-Right-Divorce-Lawyer-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_0798ef55d8" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0798ef55d8')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Choose the Right Divorce Lawyer Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e9/Choose-the-Right-Divorce-Lawyer-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Choose-the-Right-Divorce-Lawyer-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Make an appointment with your doctor.</b> If you feel there are some small changes that you need or want to make in your life to be healthier, it wouldn't hurt to see your doctor prior to making any changes.

<ul>
<li>They can review your medical history, weight and let you know what changes might be the most beneficial to you.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Develop-Critical-Thinking-Skills-Step-21-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5612690" href="#/Image:Develop-Critical-Thinking-Skills-Step-21-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Develop Critical Thinking Skills Step 21" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Develop-Critical-Thinking-Skills-Step-21-Version-3.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Develop-Critical-Thinking-Skills-Step-21-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_eea57f7167" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_eea57f7167')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Develop Critical Thinking Skills Step 21" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Develop-Critical-Thinking-Skills-Step-21-Version-3.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Develop-Critical-Thinking-Skills-Step-21-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Set goals for yourself.</b> Small goals are often the most appealing as they are the easiest to reach. If your goals are too high and you are unable to reach them in a timely manner, you may become discouraged. Set small goals that ultimately lead up to your larger goal. It will help provide you with the motivation to make and keep lifestyle changes.

<ul>
<li>When setting your goals make sure they are realistic, timely, and specific. These qualities make goals that are easier to meet in the long-term. For example, instead of a goal of "I want to boost my endurance," make your goal "I want to be able to swim five laps in my pool without needing to stop."</li>
<li>Also consider whether you need smaller goals to meet a larger, more long-term goal. For example, if you want to run five miles, you might make a goal to run a 5k (which is 3.1 miles) as an intermediary goal.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-13-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5612690" href="#/Image:Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-13-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Good About Yourself Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/58/Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-13-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_5fb6901890" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5fb6901890')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Good About Yourself Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/58/Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-13-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Write down realistic lifestyle changes.</b> Remember that too many lifestyle changes at once is a recipe for failure. It is important that you only try to implement so many changes at once. Think about what lifestyle changes you need to make in order to achieve your goals. If you don't think you'll be willing to make the lifestyle changes needed to meet your goal, revisit your goals and change them as needed.

<ul>
<li>Lifestyle changes are small changes in behavior that may result in improved health or well-being. Studies show that small lifestyle changes over long periods of time are more sustainable.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Examples of lifestyle changes include: replacing desserts with fruit or taking the stairs instead of the elevator.</li>
<li>The lifestyle changes you want to make may also help you make, change, or come up with additional goals. For example, you might want to eat healthier. A goal could be to eat a fruit or vegetable every day.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Achieve-Short-Term-Goals-Step-4-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5612690" href="#/Image:Achieve-Short-Term-Goals-Step-4-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Achieve Short Term Goals Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Achieve-Short-Term-Goals-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Achieve-Short-Term-Goals-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_ec1578db97" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ec1578db97')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Achieve Short Term Goals Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Achieve-Short-Term-Goals-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Achieve-Short-Term-Goals-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Assign a timeline for your lifestyle changes.</b> Even with small lifestyle changes, trying to accomplish multiple items at one time can be difficult and hard to keep up with.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup> Assigning your lifestyle changes to an ordered timeline can help you be more successful. Try to note which changes you'll make first, second, third, etc.

<ul>
<li>After you've come up with your goals and the lifestyle changes to help you meet them, assign an order to your list. For example: Week 1: Give up soda; Week 2: Take the stairs instead of the elevator; Week 3: Go to bed earlier.</li>
<li>Continuously reevaluate your progress. If you notice one lifestyle change in particular is giving you trouble, rework your timeline to account for that. Give yourself time to make these changes a habit. Again, if you try to work on multiple items at one time, you may be less successful.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-Adventurous-Step-5-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5612690" href="#/Image:Be-Adventurous-Step-5-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be Adventurous Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/36/Be-Adventurous-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Be-Adventurous-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_559495d08f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_559495d08f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be Adventurous Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/36/Be-Adventurous-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Be-Adventurous-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Find support.</b> It is much easier to stick to a plan when others know you're doing it. Get a support system and lean on them when necessary. Telling family, friends or coworkers about your new lifestyle changes may help keep you motivated.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>It's also helpful to surround yourself with people who are also on the same path as you making small lifestyle changes to help improve their health. You can bounce ideas off each other or work on similar goals at the same time.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('methodad'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Changing_Your_Eating_Habits_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Changing_Your_Eating_Habits">Changing Your Eating Habits</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Clear-Under-the-Skin-Pimples-Step-15.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5612690" href="#/Image:Clear-Under-the-Skin-Pimples-Step-15.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Clear Under the Skin Pimples Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a6/Clear-Under-the-Skin-Pimples-Step-15.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Clear-Under-the-Skin-Pimples-Step-15.jpg" height="546" id="img_e8417179cd" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e8417179cd')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Clear Under the Skin Pimples Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a6/Clear-Under-the-Skin-Pimples-Step-15.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Clear-Under-the-Skin-Pimples-Step-15.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Drink more water.</b> A common goal to improve your overall health is to ditch the sugary drinks and increase water intake within reason. This is a great goal as water is essential to your hydration and health.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup> Increasing water consumption is a virtually free and painless way to instantly make a positive change for yourself.

<ul>
<li>Your long-term goal should be to drink about 64 oz or 2 L of clear, sugar-free fluids every day.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Ditch sweetened beverages. Drinking more water is great, but skipping the sweetened beverages will help reduce your overall calorie intake.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Start drinking more water gradually. Add in one glass or one bottle of water than usual. Or, swap out one soda or one energy drink for an equivalent amount of water. Slowly increase the amount of water you drink and decrease the number of sweetened beverages you drink.</li>
<li>Don't drink your fruits. Drink less fruit juice and instead get nutrients from whole fruit. You'll get the added benefit of the fruit fiber in addition to missing out on the added sugar of fruit juice.</li>
<li>Beware of <i>water intoxication</i>. This is caused by drinking a large amount of water in a short time. When one is suffering from <i>water intoxication</i>, it brings the level of sodium (salt) to a dangerously low level. Water intoxication is a rare condition. It should be taken seriously, however, as it can have fatal results.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cure-Dehydration-at-Home-Step-7.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5612690" href="#/Image:Cure-Dehydration-at-Home-Step-7.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cure Dehydration at Home Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Cure-Dehydration-at-Home-Step-7.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Cure-Dehydration-at-Home-Step-7.jpg" height="546" id="img_9e1ce66815" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9e1ce66815')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cure Dehydration at Home Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Cure-Dehydration-at-Home-Step-7.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Cure-Dehydration-at-Home-Step-7.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Drink water before a meal.</b> While increasing the amount of water you drink, you can also be strategic about when you drink it. Drinking a big glass of water (about eight oz) right before a meal or snack can help decrease your appetite and how many calories you consume.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Well-Fast-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5612690" href="#/Image:Get-Well-Fast-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Well Fast Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/88/Get-Well-Fast-Step-9.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Get-Well-Fast-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_576fab0313" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_576fab0313')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Well Fast Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/88/Get-Well-Fast-Step-9.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Get-Well-Fast-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Eat a fruit and vegetable every day.</b> Eating enough fruits and vegetables is key for a healthy lifestyle and diet, since these foods are essential sources of vitamins, minerals and antioxidants. However, eating the recommended seven to nine servings of fruits and vegetables everyday may be daunting or difficult.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If you're not a big fruit or vegetable eater, make a list of your top five favorite fruits and vegetables. Start by adding in just one serving of fruit or vegetables a day. As you get comfortable with this goal, add two servings a day.</li>
<li>If you dislike many fruits and vegetables, go to the grocery and pick out something new or unfamiliar to you. Or try an item that you haven't had in a while.</li>
<li>Keep fresh fruit on the counter and vegetables cut, washed, and ready to eat in the fridge. The less preparation needed, the more likely you'll include them in your diet.</li>
<li>If you enjoy a sweet after dinner, try having fruit with your dessert.</li>
<li>Keep in mind that fruit skins have the most nutrients. Say, in an apple, keep the skin on. Don't eat pomegranate skins, even though that is where the nutrients are.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Flush-Your-Kidneys-Step-16.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5612690" href="#/Image:Flush-Your-Kidneys-Step-16.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Flush Your Kidneys Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Flush-Your-Kidneys-Step-16.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Flush-Your-Kidneys-Step-16.jpg" height="546" id="img_ea5a715701" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ea5a715701')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Flush Your Kidneys Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Flush-Your-Kidneys-Step-16.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Flush-Your-Kidneys-Step-16.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Choose whole grains when you can.</b> Whole grains are minimally processed grains that are higher in fiber, protein, and other nutrients compared to refined grains (white bread or plain pasta).<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup> They may have a more nutty flavor and chewy texture, which may not be enjoyable by all people.

<ul>
<li>If you typically eat refined grains, start by making about half of your grain choices whole grains. As you get more comfortable with this goal, you can work up to making more of your grain choices whole grains.</li>
<li>Whole grain foods to try include: 100% whole wheat pasta, oatmeal, quinoa, brown rice or 100% whole wheat bread.</li>
<li>Try a variety of whole grains and a variety of brands of whole grains. For example, try 100% whole wheat pasta. If you don't like it, try another brand of 100% whole wheat pasta as each brand has a slightly different flavor.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Thigh-Cramp-Step-7-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5612690" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Thigh-Cramp-Step-7-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Thigh Cramp Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Get-Rid-of-a-Thigh-Cramp-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Thigh-Cramp-Step-7-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_e871d943c8" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e871d943c8')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Thigh Cramp Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Get-Rid-of-a-Thigh-Cramp-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Thigh-Cramp-Step-7-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Eat healthy snacks.</b> Making lifestyle changes to be healthier doesn't mean you can't enjoy a snack. In fact, having a snack can help manage and control hunger and support weight loss.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Healthy snacks should contain some lean protein and a fruit or a vegetable. However, start slowly changing your snacks for a lasting change. For example, if you normally have a small bag of chips in the afternoon, try swapping to a small bag of whole grain chips with salsa.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Eat-Like-a-Body-Builder-Step-5-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5612690" href="#/Image:Eat-Like-a-Body-Builder-Step-5-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Eat Like a Body Builder Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Eat-Like-a-Body-Builder-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Eat-Like-a-Body-Builder-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_4a0846a5bb" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4a0846a5bb')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Eat Like a Body Builder Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Eat-Like-a-Body-Builder-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Eat-Like-a-Body-Builder-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Pack your lunch.</b> Studies show that packing your lunch can help cut down on your overall calorie intake (and food costs).<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup> Brown-bagging your lunch will give you more control over what foods you eat and how they're prepared.

<ul>
<li>If you typically eat lunch out everyday, start by packing your lunch just one to two days a week.</li>
<li>Also pack an afternoon snack if you typically stop by the vending machine to grab an afternoon pick-me-up.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Eat less high fructose corn syrup (HFCS).</b> Fructose is a sugar that goes through your body, like the glucose sugar that your body usually uses. However, fructose has its own pathways. It can turn into glucose for your muscles and brain to use, but it tends to go straight toward making fat in your body, when there is too much sugar in your body. Fructose is found in fruits and vegetables naturally, but it is found in high concentrations artificially, as High Fructose Corn Syrup.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup><ul>
<li>High fructose corn syrup is used as a sweetener so much that we don't realize it can be found in almost everything. It is in lots of processed foods, pastries, and beverages, so eating less of it might be a little difficult, but it's good to be aware of what you're eating.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Adding_in_Physical_Activity_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Adding_in_Physical_Activity">Adding in Physical Activity</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Keep-Composure-Step-15.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5612690" href="#/Image:Keep-Composure-Step-15.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Keep Composure Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Keep-Composure-Step-15.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Keep-Composure-Step-15.jpg" height="546" id="img_e6c936e7de" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e6c936e7de')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Keep Composure Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Keep-Composure-Step-15.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Keep-Composure-Step-15.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Walk more throughout the day.</b> Finding time to exercise can be difficult, especially with busy schedules or long commutes. Start adding in physical activity by increasing how many steps or how much you walk during the day.

<ul>
<li>Increasing physical activity is a great change to make to help improve your overall health. Exercise has been shown to help improve mood, increase energy, and decrease your risk of heart disease and high blood pressure.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Even without planned exercise each day, adding extra steps can be beneficial to your health. Try: taking the stairs instead of the elevator, parking father away, delivering messages in person instead of email at work, walking while you talk on the phone, or take a walk on your lunch break.</li>
<li>You burn more calories walking at a faster pace than you do at a slower pace.</li>
<li>You can also consider purchasing a pedometer to help see how many steps you take and monitor your progress of increasing your total steps.</li>
<li>Try the "one mile rule." This means that you can walk to the store, school, work or other locations if they are less than one mile away (and it's a safe walk). Skip taking the bus or driving!</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-Neck-Fat-Step-6-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5612690" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-Neck-Fat-Step-6-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Neck Fat Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/31/Get-Rid-of-Neck-Fat-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Neck-Fat-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_06e61f1e5f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_06e61f1e5f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Neck Fat Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/31/Get-Rid-of-Neck-Fat-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Neck-Fat-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Add in planned cardio.</b> Additional exercise outside of lifestyle activity (like taking the stairs), greatly adds to the health benefits provided by exercise. Plan cardio so that you're getting targeted exercise that benefits your heart and overall health. You'll see additional improvements in weight, mood and overall health.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>The USDA states that you should aim for 150 minutes or about 2 1/2 hours of moderate-intensity physical activity each week.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup> Moderate intensity activity is any exercise that increases your heart rate and makes you breathe harder and work up a slight sweat.</li>
<li>If this recommendation is too much, start with half of that amount. Or break up that time in small bits. For example, a brisk 10-minute walk at breakfast, lunch and dinner five days a week meets your 150-minute goal.</li>
<li>Also, if you cannot do moderate intensity at first, do 150 minutes of lower intensity exercises. For example, walking counts as a lower intensity exercise. Any activity is better than none.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-Neck-Fat-Step-7-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5612690" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-Neck-Fat-Step-7-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Neck Fat Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Get-Rid-of-Neck-Fat-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Neck-Fat-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_9f1e7d75de" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9f1e7d75de')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Neck Fat Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Get-Rid-of-Neck-Fat-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Neck-Fat-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Add in some resistance training.</b> Not all strength training exercises require you to spend time at the gym. There are plenty of easy to do exercises at home that require little to no equipment.

<ul>
<li>It's recommended to include 20 minutes of strength training two days a week. Including strength training helps build lean muscle mass which can increase your metabolism and how many calories your body burns at rest.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 18" class="reference" id="_ref-18"><a href="#_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Easy, no equipment required exercises include: lunges, push-ups, sit-ups, squats, or wall sits.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Not-Feel-Step-6.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5612690" href="#/Image:Not-Feel-Step-6.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Not Feel Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Not-Feel-Step-6.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Not-Feel-Step-6.jpg" height="546" id="img_4ed09c4930" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4ed09c4930')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Not Feel Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Not-Feel-Step-6.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Not-Feel-Step-6.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Look for social, fun exercise opportunities.</b> Go to the pool with your little brother, take a walk with your best friend, chase your daughter around the playground, or play backyard sports with your family.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Learn-Something-New-Every-Day-Step-6-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5612690" href="#/Image:Learn-Something-New-Every-Day-Step-6-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Learn Something New Every Day Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/52/Learn-Something-New-Every-Day-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Learn-Something-New-Every-Day-Step-6-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_b8751f6d51" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b8751f6d51')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Learn Something New Every Day Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/52/Learn-Something-New-Every-Day-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid5612690-v4-728px-Learn-Something-New-Every-Day-Step-6-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Move while you watch TV.</b> If you aren't ready for the gym or more intense exercise, try moving while you watch your favorite TV programs. Get up during the commercial breaks and fit in a few minutes of activity.

<ul>
<li>Try running or walking in place, or some strength training exercises. Since commercial breaks are about two minutes, you can burn about 270 calories during two hours of TV time.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 19" class="reference" id="_ref-19"><a href="#_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Sit on an exercise ball in front of your desk or TV.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions qa_no_answered" data-aid="5612690" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">

<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>

</div>
<div class="qa_divider qa_no_unpatrolled_questions"></div>

<input id="qa_asked_question" maxlength="200" placeholder="What do you need to know? We'll do our best to find the answer." type="text"/><div id="qa_asked_count">200 characters left</div>
<input id="qa_email" placeholder="Email address (optional)" type="text"/><div id="qa_email_prompt">Include your email address to get a message when this question is answered.</div>

</div>
<!--  Template for rendering a submitted question -->
<script id="qa_submitted_question_item" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
				<li class="qa_sq" data-sqid="{{id}}">
	<div class="qa_divider"></div>

		<div class="qa_bullet"></div>

			<div class="qa_q_txt">{{{text}}}</div>
			<div class="qa_editor_tools">
				<a class="qa_edit_submitted {{#qa_desktop}}button secondary{{/qa_desktop}}">{{qa_curate}}</a>
				{{^mobile_anon_user}}
				<a class="qa_flag_submitted" data-type="sq_flag">{{qa_flag}}</a>
				<a class="qa_ignore_submitted" data-type="sq_ignore">{{qa_ignore}}</a>
				{{/mobile_anon_user}}
			</div>
		</div>
	</div>
</li>

			</script><!--  Template for answer confirmation  --><script id="qa_answer_confirmation" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
				<div class="qa_answer_confirmation">

	<span class="x_button"></span>

	<div class="qa_answer_confirmation_response">
		<span class="qa_checkmark"></span>
		<div class="qa_social_login_heading standalone">{{qa_proposed_answer_confirmation}}</div>
	</div>

</div>


			</script><!--  Template form for creating/updating a curated question  --><script id="qa_question_edit_form" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
				<div class="qa_aq_edit_form">
	<div class="qa_aq_edit_form_status"></div>
	<textarea class="qa_cq_text" spellcheck="true" placeholder="{{qa_edit_form_question_placeholder}}">{{qa_edit_form_question}}</textarea>
	<div class="qa_invalid_msg qa_cq_text_error qap_char_limit">{{qa_cq_text_error}}</div>
	<textarea class="qa_ca_text" spellcheck="true" placeholder="{{qa_edit_form_answer_placeholder}}">{{qa_edit_form_answer}}</textarea>
	<div class="qa_invalid_msg qa_ca_text_error qap_char_limit">{{qa_ca_text_error}}</div>
	<div class="qa_invalid_msg qa_ca_text_error2 qap_char_limit">{{qa_ca_text_min}}</div>
	<div class="qa_invalid_msg qa_ca_text_error3 qap_char_limit">{{qa_ca_error_url}}</div>
	<div class="qa_invalid_msg qa_ca_text_error_phone qap_char_limit">{{qa_ca_error_phone}}</div>
	<input class="qa_pa_email" placeholder="{{qa_pa_email_placeholder}}"/>

	{{#qa_admin}}
		<span class="qa_edit_form_verifier_container">
			{{qa_edit_form_verifier_label}}
			<select class="qa_edit_form_verifier">
				{{#qa_edit_form_verifiers}}
					<option value="{{id}}" {{selected}}>{{name}}</option>
				{{/qa_edit_form_verifiers}}
			</select>
		</span>
		{{#qa_edit_form_show_remove_submitter}}

			<label for="qa_aq_remove_submitter">{{qa_edit_form_remove_submitter}}</label> <input type="checkbox" id="qa_aq_remove_submitter" class="qa_checkbox" />
		</span>
		{{/qa_edit_form_show_remove_submitter}}
	{{/qa_admin}}

	<span class="qa_edit_form_inactive_container">
		<label for="qa_aq_inactive">{{qa_edit_form_inactive}}</label> <input type="checkbox" id="qa_aq_inactive" class="qa_checkbox" {{qa_edit_form_inactive_val}}>
	</span>

	<div class="clearall"></div>

	{{#qa_admin}}<a class="qa_aq_delete button primary">{{qa_edit_form_delete}}</a>{{/qa_admin}}
	<a class="qa_aq_submit button primary">{{qa_edit_form_submit}}</a>
	<span class="qa_spinner"></span>
	<a class="qa_aq_cancel button secondary">{{qa_edit_form_cancel}}</a>

<div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>Talk to your doctor prior to making any major dietary changes. Also talk to your doctor prior to starting an exercise program. It's important to know whether or not these changes are safe and healthy for you.</li>
<li>Play a sport that you enjoy. Exercising definitely doesn't have to be a chore!</li>
<li>Once you have reached your goal, don't go back to your old habits. It will make all the work you just did go to waste.</li>
<li>Minimize food-related rewards for your efforts. If you give yourself too many, you may counteract your hard work.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

    "author": {

    "aggregateRating": {

        "@type": "Organization",

        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,

        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",

    "contributor": {
        "@type": "Person",
        "name": "Claudia Carberry, RD"
    },
    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Planning for a Healthier Lifestyle",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Make an appointment with your doctor. If you feel there are some small changes that you need or want to make in your life to be healthier, it wouldn't hurt to see your doctor prior to making any changes.\n\nThey can review your medical history, weight and let you know what changes might be the most beneficial to you."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Set goals for yourself. Small goals are often the most appealing as they are the easiest to reach. If your goals are too high and you are unable to reach them in a timely manner, you may become discouraged. Set small goals that ultimately lead up to your larger goal. It will help provide you with the motivation to make and keep lifestyle changes.\n\nWhen setting your goals make sure they are realistic, timely, and specific. These qualities make goals that are easier to meet in the long-term. For example, instead of a goal of \"I want to boost my endurance,\" make your goal \"I want to be able to swim five laps in my pool without needing to stop.\"\nAlso consider whether you need smaller goals to meet a larger, more long-term goal. For example, if you want to run five miles, you might make a goal to run a 5k (which is 3.1 miles) as an intermediary goal."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Write down realistic lifestyle changes. Remember that too many lifestyle changes at once is a recipe for failure. It is important that you only try to implement so many changes at once. Think about what lifestyle changes you need to make in order to achieve your goals. If you don't think you'll be willing to make the lifestyle changes needed to meet your goal, revisit your goals and change them as needed.\n\nLifestyle changes are small changes in behavior that may result in improved health or well-being. Studies show that small lifestyle changes over long periods of time are more sustainable.[2]\nExamples of lifestyle changes include: replacing desserts with fruit or taking the stairs instead of the elevator.\nThe lifestyle changes you want to make may also help you make, change, or come up with additional goals. For example, you might want to eat healthier. A goal could be to eat a fruit or vegetable every day."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Assign a timeline for your lifestyle changes. Even with small lifestyle changes, trying to accomplish multiple items at one time can be difficult and hard to keep up with.[3] Assigning your lifestyle changes to an ordered timeline can help you be more successful. Try to note which changes you'll make first, second, third, etc.\n\nAfter you've come up with your goals and the lifestyle changes to help you meet them, assign an order to your list. For example: Week 1: Give up soda; Week 2: Take the stairs instead of the elevator; Week 3: Go to bed earlier.\nContinuously reevaluate your progress. If you notice one lifestyle change in particular is giving you trouble, rework your timeline to account for that. Give yourself time to make these changes a habit. Again, if you try to work on multiple items at one time, you may be less successful."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Find support. It is much easier to stick to a plan when others know you're doing it. Get a support system and lean on them when necessary. Telling family, friends or coworkers about your new lifestyle changes may help keep you motivated.[4]\nIt's also helpful to surround yourself with people who are also on the same path as you making small lifestyle changes to help improve their health. You can bounce ideas off each other or work on similar goals at the same time."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Changing Your Eating Habits",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Drink more water. A common goal to improve your overall health is to ditch the sugary drinks and increase water intake within reason. This is a great goal as water is essential to your hydration and health.[5] Increasing water consumption is a virtually free and painless way to instantly make a positive change for yourself.\n\nYour long-term goal should be to drink about 64 oz or 2 L of clear, sugar-free fluids every day.[6]\nDitch sweetened beverages. Drinking more water is great, but skipping the sweetened beverages will help reduce your overall calorie intake.[7]\nStart drinking more water gradually. Add in one glass or one bottle of water than usual. Or, swap out one soda or one energy drink for an equivalent amount of water. Slowly increase the amount of water you drink and decrease the number of sweetened beverages you drink.\nDon't drink your fruits. Drink less fruit juice and instead get nutrients from whole fruit. You'll get the added benefit of the fruit fiber in addition to missing out on the added sugar of fruit juice.\nBeware of water intoxication. This is caused by drinking a large amount of water in a short time. When one is suffering from water intoxication, it brings the level of sodium (salt) to a dangerously low level. Water intoxication is a rare condition. It should be taken seriously, however, as it can have fatal results.[8]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Drink water before a meal. While increasing the amount of water you drink, you can also be strategic about when you drink it. Drinking a big glass of water (about eight oz) right before a meal or snack can help decrease your appetite and how many calories you consume.[9]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Eat a fruit and vegetable every day. Eating enough fruits and vegetables is key for a healthy lifestyle and diet, since these foods are essential sources of vitamins, minerals and antioxidants. However, eating the recommended seven to nine servings of fruits and vegetables everyday may be daunting or difficult.[10]\nIf you're not a big fruit or vegetable eater, make a list of your top five favorite fruits and vegetables. Start by adding in just one serving of fruit or vegetables a day. As you get comfortable with this goal, add two servings a day.\nIf you dislike many fruits and vegetables, go to the grocery and pick out something new or unfamiliar to you. Or try an item that you haven't had in a while.\nKeep fresh fruit on the counter and vegetables cut, washed, and ready to eat in the fridge. The less preparation needed, the more likely you'll include them in your diet.\nIf you enjoy a sweet after dinner, try having fruit with your dessert.\nKeep in mind that fruit skins have the most nutrients. Say, in an apple, keep the skin on. Don't eat pomegranate skins, even though that is where the nutrients are."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Choose whole grains when you can. Whole grains are minimally processed grains that are higher in fiber, protein, and other nutrients compared to refined grains (white bread or plain pasta).[11] They may have a more nutty flavor and chewy texture, which may not be enjoyable by all people.\n\nIf you typically eat refined grains, start by making about half of your grain choices whole grains. As you get more comfortable with this goal, you can work up to making more of your grain choices whole grains.\nWhole grain foods to try include: 100% whole wheat pasta, oatmeal, quinoa, brown rice or 100% whole wheat bread.\nTry a variety of whole grains and a variety of brands of whole grains. For example, try 100% whole wheat pasta. If you don't like it, try another brand of 100% whole wheat pasta as each brand has a slightly different flavor."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Eat healthy snacks. Making lifestyle changes to be healthier doesn't mean you can't enjoy a snack. In fact, having a snack can help manage and control hunger and support weight loss.[12]\nHealthy snacks should contain some lean protein and a fruit or a vegetable. However, start slowly changing your snacks for a lasting change. For example, if you normally have a small bag of chips in the afternoon, try swapping to a small bag of whole grain chips with salsa."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 6,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Pack your lunch. Studies show that packing your lunch can help cut down on your overall calorie intake (and food costs).[13] Brown-bagging your lunch will give you more control over what foods you eat and how they're prepared.\n\nIf you typically eat lunch out everyday, start by packing your lunch just one to two days a week.\nAlso pack an afternoon snack if you typically stop by the vending machine to grab an afternoon pick-me-up."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 7,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Eat less high fructose corn syrup (HFCS). Fructose is a sugar that goes through your body, like the glucose sugar that your body usually uses. However, fructose has its own pathways. It can turn into glucose for your muscles and brain to use, but it tends to go straight toward making fat in your body, when there is too much sugar in your body. Fructose is found in fruits and vegetables naturally, but it is found in high concentrations artificially, as High Fructose Corn Syrup.[14]High fructose corn syrup is used as a sweetener so much that we don't realize it can be found in almost everything. It is in lots of processed foods, pastries, and beverages, so eating less of it might be a little difficult, but it's good to be aware of what you're eating."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Adding in Physical Activity",
            "position": 3,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Walk more throughout the day. Finding time to exercise can be difficult, especially with busy schedules or long commutes. Start adding in physical activity by increasing how many steps or how much you walk during the day.\n\nIncreasing physical activity is a great change to make to help improve your overall health. Exercise has been shown to help improve mood, increase energy, and decrease your risk of heart disease and high blood pressure.[15]\nEven without planned exercise each day, adding extra steps can be beneficial to your health. Try: taking the stairs instead of the elevator, parking father away, delivering messages in person instead of email at work, walking while you talk on the phone, or take a walk on your lunch break.\nYou burn more calories walking at a faster pace than you do at a slower pace.\nYou can also consider purchasing a pedometer to help see how many steps you take and monitor your progress of increasing your total steps.\nTry the \"one mile rule.\" This means that you can walk to the store, school, work or other locations if they are less than one mile away (and it's a safe walk). Skip taking the bus or driving!"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Add in planned cardio. Additional exercise outside of lifestyle activity (like taking the stairs), greatly adds to the health benefits provided by exercise. Plan cardio so that you're getting targeted exercise that benefits your heart and overall health. You'll see additional improvements in weight, mood and overall health.[16]\nThe USDA states that you should aim for 150 minutes or about 2 1\/2 hours of moderate-intensity physical activity each week.[17] Moderate intensity activity is any exercise that increases your heart rate and makes you breathe harder and work up a slight sweat.\nIf this recommendation is too much, start with half of that amount. Or break up that time in small bits. For example, a brisk 10-minute walk at breakfast, lunch and dinner five days a week meets your 150-minute goal.\nAlso, if you cannot do moderate intensity at first, do 150 minutes of lower intensity exercises. For example, walking counts as a lower intensity exercise. Any activity is better than none."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Add in some resistance training. Not all strength training exercises require you to spend time at the gym. There are plenty of easy to do exercises at home that require little to no equipment.\n\nIt's recommended to include 20 minutes of strength training two days a week. Including strength training helps build lean muscle mass which can increase your metabolism and how many calories your body burns at rest.[18]\nEasy, no equipment required exercises include: lunges, push-ups, sit-ups, squats, or wall sits."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Look for social, fun exercise opportunities. Go to the pool with your little brother, take a walk with your best friend, chase your daughter around the playground, or play backyard sports with your family."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Move while you watch TV. If you aren't ready for the gym or more intense exercise, try moving while you watch your favorite TV programs. Get up during the commercial breaks and fit in a few minutes of activity.\n\nTry running or walking in place, or some strength training exercises. Since commercial breaks are about two minutes, you can burn about 270 calories during two hours of TV time.[19]\nSit on an exercise ball in front of your desk or TV."
                    }
                }
            ]
        }
    ],
    "description": "How to Be Healthier Without a Dramatic Lifestyle Change. Many diet or exercise programs require major lifestyle changes, long-term commitments and or pricey products or equipment. For a lot people, these programs are not reasonable or even..."
